By LIZ WALLACE
William H. Masters, M.D. and
Virginia E. Johnson, nationally
renowned researchers in human
sexuality, will kick-off the 1974
Milton S. Eisenhower
Symposium October 10 at 4:00
in Shriver Hall.
Masters and Johnson have
spent 14 years of investigation at
their Reproductive Biology
Research Foundation in St.
Louis, Missouri. They initiated
the concept of sex clinics and
have demonstrated that "sexual
dysfunction" is treatable.
Their research work has
basically covered the physical,

psychological and social aspects
of the sex lives of hundreds of
study-subjects. Their early work
was focused on the physiology of
the 'sex act itself.
The program involved direct
observations of 10,000 orgasms
achieved through coitus with
partners or through
automanipulation.
Masters and Johnson have
applied what they have learned
to develop techniques for dealing
with frigidity or impotence.
Their work has been termed a
breakthrough in the medical
profession, for physicians had as
little concrete knowledge about

sexual physiology as the general
public.
Dr. Ghislaine Godenne, a
psychiatrist and psychologist
who he-ads the counseling service
on campus, termed the Masters
and Johnson work "scientifically
excellent." Dr. Ted Knowles,
another psychiatrist, concurred.
Masters and Johnson have
trained seven man-woman pairs
of co-therapists who now run
clinics of their own.

Budget Advisory Committee implemented
By LAINY STEPHANS
The Budget Advisory
Committee (BAC) originally
proposed last year by
then-Student Council Treasurer
Jon Tillem and Eric Rasmussen
will be implemented this year,
revealed Alan Fink, SC Treasurer.
The BAC, to be chaired by the
Student Council Treasurer, will
be a 13-person board to provide
"student input on budgeting
procedures and policy changes,"
revealed Alan Fink, who will
chair the new committee.
Committee members, to be
chosen from the student body,
will be assigned to individual
administrators as "unofficial
ombudsmen" explained Leah
Seidenfeld, Secretary of the SC
and assistant chairperson of the
commit tee.
"The committee will first

sit down and estimate the
priorities of student viewpoints
on budgeting policies," Fink
stated.
They will then meet with
Homewood Vice President
George Benton to decide which
suggestion are feasible, before
committee members are sent to
individual offices.
One member of the committee
will be assigned to Larry Denton,
Director of Academic Services, to
relay student opinions on
admission, financial .aid, student
employment and placement.
Committee members will also
be responsible to MSE Librarian
David Stain to confer on library
policy; Dean Owen, Arts and
Sciences; Dr. Wickwire,
Chaplain's Office; William
Campbell, Plant Operations and
Security, including parking; Glen

Thomas, Director of Admission;
and Solis James, of the
Computing Center.
Co-chairwoman Seidenfeld will
be assigned to Dean Fitzpatrick
to- "have constant, weekly
meetings to provide student
input" on student life.
The remaining five committee
members will form' a
sub-committee on student
activities under Seidenfeld to
refer undergraduate opinions to
the Athletic Center, the Student
Health Service, the Director of
Student Activities, the Food
Service, and the dormitories.
•
After learning of
administrative policies and
relaying student feeling, the
entire committee will meet to
"correlate the information,"
Fink explained. "At this meeting
we will discuss the amount of

money the offices receive and
how much they want for the
future. We will examine how
their policies affect student life
and discuss possible changes."
. Thrust
Fink saw the major thrust of
the Committee as affecting the
Dean of Student's Office, while
Seidenfeld expects more of an
"equalized thrust, especially
concentrating on areas that have
not yet been covered," she
explained.
Both are optimistic that the
committee will cause subtle
policy changes.
The commit tee, originally
conceived last spring by Eric
Rasmussen and Jon Tillem, was
approved by Benton but never
implemented. "Last year, there
just wasn't enough response to
fill it," commented Fink.

Council members meet, discuss role of SC Presidency

Seth Feltheimer

By BOB BUCHANAN
An ad hoc committee of
Student ,Council members,
headed by Senior Class President
Seth Feltheimer, met last
Saturday afternoon to discuss the
role of the SC President in the
selection of student
representatives for the various
Homewood committees and
chairmen for the Council
sponsored social events.
According to Feltheimer,
dissatisfaction on the part of
Council members with the
behaviour of SC President Andy
Savitz at last Wednesday's
meeting gave rise to the meeting.
"At the Wednesday meeting,"
asserted Feltheimer, "Savitz was
telling people what they did and

did not have the power to do."
"He eventually lost control of
the 'meeting,"he continued.
"Everyone was upset."
In attendance Saturday were
Feltheimer, SC Vice President
Eric Rosenson, Secretary Leah
Seidenfeld, Treasurer Alan Fink,
Senior Representative Andy
Fredman, and Sophomore
Representative Eric Molander.
Savitz's remarks at the
Wednesday meeting with respect
to his perogative, as Council
President, to overrule all choices
made by the SC Selections
Committee, led the group to
draw up several tentative
proposals concerning the
selections process to be presented
to the Council as a whole at its

Saga to use non-union lettuce
In response to the plight of the
United Fa rmworkers (UFW),
Saga, the Hopkins Food service,
will no longer serve Union
lettuce, revealed Univesity
Chaplain Chester Wickwire.
Tom Tanglos, head of the
Hopkins Saga branch, announced
to Wickwire yesterday that he
will be able to substitute
non-Union iceberg lettuce from
Flordia for Union lettuce,
beginning this Friday.
As a result of Caesar Chavez's
recent speech at Hopkins on the
lettuce and grape boycott, "a
series of amicable meetings were
caned between Tanglos, Bob
Ivanhoe of the Union Governing
Board, Peter Velasco, local head
of the United Farmworker's, and
my office," explained Wickwire.
Valesco stressed the problems
of the farmworkers, and the
necessity for cooperation in the
boycott by institutions sensitive
to their plight. "The UFW have
found students very sensitive and
sympathetic," the Chaplain said.
Ivanhoe revealed that the
University's representatives at the
meetings "agreed in principle
with serving non-Union lettuce,
and we had to determine
reasonable alternatives."
Alternatives suggested
included serving non-local,
non-union lettuce, non-iceberg

lettuce or several California
brands, such as "Black Eagle",
none of which are covered by the
boycott.
"The Florida iceberg chosen
by Tanglos is slightly cheaper
and leafier than Union lettuce
that had been served," Ivanhoe
explained.
The Chaplain stated that no
problems are anticipated in
obtaining the new produce," but
we may need to look for another
state, other than Florida, if the
season there ends."
Wickwire commented that his
office had received several
complaints from students asking
what could be done to support
the boycott. He cited Chavez's
speech and recent publicity in
major newspapers on the boycott
of Gallo wines as motivating
forces in finding a supplier of
non-Union lettuce.
Ivanhoe stated that he had
received "under 10 complaints
from students. They weren't very
persistent, but we decided to
cooperate with the boycott, if we
could do it without hurting the
food service."
Tomorrow, Wickwire has
schedule a meeting at Loyola
College and one at Hopkins
Medical School on Thursday to
see if similar boycotts can be
instituted there.

Larcenies plague campus
Six incidents of theft were
reported to campus security
officials this past week,including
two auto thefts, as larcenies on
campus increased substantially
over last week.
The two alleged auto thefts
took place on "J" lot, the lower
lot on Remington Avenue and
San Martin Drive
One of the
autos was recovered on the lot
the day after it was reported
stolen, prompting security
officials to wonder if the vehicle
was ever stolen at all. The
ignition lock on the car had
apparently been tampered with.
The other auto has not as yet
been recovered. Its value has
not
yet
, been determined.

The Selections proposal calls
for a revision of the SC
President's veto power, to the
effect that the President can only
appoint students to committees
if the Council does not approve
the Selections Committee's
choices after at least one
resubmission to the Selections
Committee. The Council
President will only be able to
select students for the committee
in that event, from the regular
pool of applicants for the
positions.
At last Wednesday's Council
meeting, SC President Andy
Savitz stressed to the Council
that he currentlyholds the
technical executive authority to
appoint anyone he deems fit to
any committee.
However, Council members
were obviously hampered in their
efforts to determine the
constitutionality
of the
president's power since no one
had a constitution.
Constitutions
The present constitution was
rewritten and heavily amended
by Savitz and other students,
who have since graduated, three
years ago. The 'constitutions and
amendments promulgated by
Councils in the past have not
been dated, so that it is hard to
determine which Constitution
and which amendments take
precedence over which.
Said Feltheimer:"We've been
on the SC a month and haven't
seen the constitution yet."
The SC members also
considered the issue of student
salaries for SC sponsored

It Sounds
Incredible
(

BUT EVELYN WOOD GRADUATES CAN READ
THE EXORCIST IN 58 MINUTES

You can do it, too. So far over 550,000 other people have done it. People who
have different jobs, different IQs, different interests, different educations have
completed the course. Our graduates are people from all walks of life. These
people have all taken a course developed by Evelyn Wood, a prominent
educator. Practically all of them at least tripled their reading speed with equal or
better comprehension. Most have increased it even more.
Think for a moment what that means. All of them—even the slowest—now read
an average novel in less than two hours. They read an entire issue of Time or
Newsweek in 35 minutes. They don't skip or skim. They read every word. They
use no machines. Instead, they let the material they're reading determine how
fast they read. And mark this well: they actually understand more, remember
more, and enjoy more than when they read slowly. That's right! They
understand more. They remember more. They enjoy more. You can do the same
thing—the place to learn more about it is at a free speed reading lesson.

At That Speed, The 403 Pages Come Across
With More Impact Than The Movie.
In Living Blood, You Might Say.

This is the same course President Kennedy had his Joint Chiefs of Staff take.
The staff of President Nixon completed this course in June 1970. The same one
Senators and Congressmen have taken.
Come to a Mini-Lesson and find out. It is free to you and you will leave with a
better understanding of why it works. One thing that might bother you about
your reading speed is that someone might find out how slow it is. The
instructors at the Evelyn Wood Reading Dynamics Free Speed Reading lesson
will let you keep your secret. It's true we practice the first step to improved
reading at a Mini-Lesson and we will increase your reading speed on the spot, but
the results will remain your secret. Plan to attend a free Mini-Lesson and learn
that it is possible to read 3-4-5 times faster, with comparable comprehension.

By ELLEN L. BERNHARD
Last week's Sunday
Experience program, sponsored
by the Office of the Chaplain,
presented "The Great Rip-Off", a
panel disucssion between Student
Council President Andy Savitz
Bob Ivanhoe, a member of th(
Union Governing Board, Hono
Commission Chairwoman Ann
Connor, and Judge Gerstung of
the Baltimore City Criminal
Court.
Concurring that this is "the
age of the rip-off," the panelists

discussed the question of
punishment for Hopkins'
students caught stealing on
campus. Savitz said that he was
unwilling to take a hard line
attitude because he sees "where
and why the problems arise."
"The worst example of a
rip-off is in political leaders who
should set examples, but don't,"
he said, citing Watergate and the
recent pardon of former
President Richard Nixon by
President Gerald Ford. "I don't
believe the problems of the

University can be solved until
someone solves the problems of
the nation."
Judge Gerstung, a Hopkins
alumnus, advocated a hardline
intolerance of crime. Illustrating
a "decline of morals," he asserted
that when he was a Hopkins
student during the 1950's, crime
on the campus was not as
widespread as it is now.
"Leaders in society have
looked too much to the people,"
said the Judge in refutation of
Savitz's statement. "The people

Hopkins Blue Jays kicked in the teeth by F&M Mules
By STEPHEN LEVIN
It was a dismal Saturday night
at Homewood Field as the
Hopkins football team was badly
beaten, 63-13, by the -unbeaten
Diplomats of Franklin &
Marshall. A school which focuses
all the energies of its athletic
department on their football
program, Franklin & Marshall
always has a fine team and are a
perennial conference
powerhouse. They are the

NEWS-LETTER

defending champs and boast 17
returning starters from last year's
8-1 squad (including a 28-7 win
over the Blue Jays).
This year's Diplomat squad
proved to be no bunch of
slouches either. Boasting an
offense that could move either
on the ground or through the air,
the Lancaster eleven ran up 555
yards in total offense on the
seemingly helpless Blue Jay
defense. F&M quarterback Joe

Coviello paced the Diplomats
aerial attack which (utilizing 3
QB's) completed a spectacular 81
or 28 passes for 227 yards, 4
touchdowns and no
interceptions. On the ground, the
Diplomats made it look easy as
they ripped through the Hopkins
defense for 328 yards in 56
carries (an incredible average of
over 5.8 yards per carry).
Leading the onslaught was the
Diplomats top rusher, Ted

Blue Jay hooters blank the Bears
By JOHN BLOOMENTHAL
The Hopkins booters collected
their first victory of the season,
blanking the Bears of Ursinus
College 3-0 Saturday.
From the outset, the game was
really no contest. Hopkins had
little difficulty in overpowering
their rivals and glided. easily to
their first season victory. The win
left the Blue Jays 1-1 in the
conference and 1-2- overall.
Freshman Gary Cunningham
put the Blue Jays on top early in
the first period, scoring a head
shot oof an assist! by Gary
Ignatowski. Only 48 seconds had
elapsed on the time clock when
Cunningham blasted in the first
goal. Cunningham put in another
goal 28 minutes later on an assist
by Tom Myrick. Cunningham put
in Hopkins third and final goal
late in the second period from an
assist by Larry McGowan.
Cunningham
With three goals to his credit
for the day, Cunningham was just
one goal short of the Hopkins
record for the most 'goals scored
in one game. That record is
currently held by last year's top
scorer Roberto Arguero.
It was a good day for others
on the squad as well. Coach
Robert Oliver called deep back
Ami Cohen's play "admirable."
Bruce Casenave, who has
developed rapidly as the season
has progressed, now owning a

spot on the starting lineup,
"played one of the best games in
his career at Hopkins."
The statistic of the contest
were extremely lopsided.
Hopkins took 27 shots on goal
and had 11 corner kicks. Ursinus,

on the defensive most of the
game, managed to get off only 8
shots on goal and only 2
cornerkicks.
The Blue Jays face Towson
State tomorrow at 4 p.m. at
Homewood Field.

of any set.

By LIZ WALLACE
William H. Masters, M.D. and
Virginia E. Johnson, nationally
renowned researchers in human
sexuality, will kick-off the 1974
Milton S. Eisenhower
Symposium October 10 at 4:00
in Shriver Hall.
Masters and Johnson have
spent 14 years of investigation at
their Reproductive Biology
Research Foundation in St.
Louis, Missouri. They initiated
the concept of sex clinics and
have demonstrated that "sexual
dysfunction" is treatable.
Their research work has
basically covered the physical,

psychological and social aspects
of the sex lives of hundreds of
study-subjects. Their early work
was focused on the physiology of
the 'sex act itself.
The program involved direct
observations of 10,000 orgasms
achieved through coitus with
partners or through
automanipulation.
Masters and Johnson have
applied what they have learned
to develop techniques for dealing
with frigidity or impotence.
Their work has been termed a
breakthrough in the medical
profession, for physicians had as
little concrete knowledge about

sexual physiology as the general
public.
Dr. Ghislaine Godenne, a
psychiatrist and psychologist
who he-ads the counseling service
on campus, termed the Masters
and Johnson work "scientifically
excellent." Dr. Ted Knowles,
another psychiatrist, concurred.
Masters and Johnson have
trained seven man-woman pairs
of co-therapists who now run
clinics of their own.

Budget Advisory Committee implemented
By LAINY STEPHANS
The Budget Advisory
Committee (BAC) originally
proposed last year by
then-Student Council Treasurer
Jon Tillem and Eric Rasmussen
will be implemented this year,
revealed Alan Fink, SC Treasurer.
The BAC, to be chaired by the
Student Council Treasurer, will
be a 13-person board to provide
"student input on budgeting
procedures and policy changes,"
revealed Alan Fink, who will
chair the new committee.
Committee members, to be
chosen from the student body,
will be assigned to individual
administrators as "unofficial
ombudsmen" explained Leah
Seidenfeld, Secretary of the SC
and assistant chairperson of the
commit tee.
"The committee will first

sit down and estimate the
priorities of student viewpoints
on budgeting policies," Fink
stated.
They will then meet with
Homewood Vice President
George Benton to decide which
suggestion are feasible, before
committee members are sent to
individual offices.
One member of the committee
will be assigned to Larry Denton,
Director of Academic Services, to
relay student opinions on
admission, financial .aid, student
employment and placement.
Committee members will also
be responsible to MSE Librarian
David Stain to confer on library
policy; Dean Owen, Arts and
Sciences; Dr. Wickwire,
Chaplain's Office; William
Campbell, Plant Operations and
Security, including parking; Glen

Thomas, Director of Admission;
and Solis James, of the
Computing Center.
Co-chairwoman Seidenfeld will
be assigned to Dean Fitzpatrick
to- "have constant, weekly
meetings to provide student
input" on student life.
The remaining five committee
members will form' a
sub-committee on student
activities under Seidenfeld to
refer undergraduate opinions to
the Athletic Center, the Student
Health Service, the Director of
Student Activities, the Food
Service, and the dormitories.
•
After learning of
administrative policies and
relaying student feeling, the
entire committee will meet to
"correlate the information,"
Fink explained. "At this meeting
we will discuss the amount of

money the offices receive and
how much they want for the
future. We will examine how
their policies affect student life
and discuss possible changes."
. Thrust
Fink saw the major thrust of
the Committee as affecting the
Dean of Student's Office, while
Seidenfeld expects more of an
"equalized thrust, especially
concentrating on areas that have
not yet been covered," she
explained.
Both are optimistic that the
committee will cause subtle
policy changes.
The commit tee, originally
conceived last spring by Eric
Rasmussen and Jon Tillem, was
approved by Benton but never
implemented. "Last year, there
just wasn't enough response to
fill it," commented Fink.

By BOB BUCHANAN
An ad hoc committee of
Student ,Council members,
headed by Senior Class President
Seth Feltheimer, met last
Saturday afternoon to discuss the
role of the SC President in the
selection of student
representatives for the various
Homewood committees and
chairmen for the Council
sponsored social events.
According to Feltheimer,
dissatisfaction on the part of
Council members with the
behaviour of SC President Andy
Savitz at last Wednesday's
meeting gave rise to the meeting.
"At the Wednesday meeting,"
asserted Feltheimer, "Savitz was
telling people what they did and

did not have the power to do."
"He eventually lost control of
the 'meeting,"he continued.
"Everyone was upset."
In attendance Saturday were
Feltheimer, SC Vice President
Eric Rosenson, Secretary Leah
Seidenfeld, Treasurer Alan Fink,
Senior Representative Andy
Fredman, and Sophomore
Representative Eric Molander.
Savitz's remarks at the
Wednesday meeting with respect
to his perogative, as Council
President, to overrule all choices
made by the SC Selections
Committee, led the group to
draw up several tentative
proposals concerning the
selections process to be presented
to the Council as a whole at its

Saga to use non-union lettuce
In response to the plight of the
United Fa rmworkers (UFW),
Saga, the Hopkins Food service,
will no longer serve Union
lettuce, revealed Univesity
Chaplain Chester Wickwire.
Tom Tanglos, head of the
Hopkins Saga branch, announced
to Wickwire yesterday that he
will be able to substitute
non-Union iceberg lettuce from
Flordia for Union lettuce,
beginning this Friday.
As a result of Caesar Chavez's
recent speech at Hopkins on the
lettuce and grape boycott, "a
series of amicable meetings were
caned between Tanglos, Bob
Ivanhoe of the Union Governing
Board, Peter Velasco, local head
of the United Farmworker's, and
my office," explained Wickwire.
Valesco stressed the problems
of the farmworkers, and the
necessity for cooperation in the
boycott by institutions sensitive
to their plight. "The UFW have
found students very sensitive and
sympathetic," the Chaplain said.
Ivanhoe revealed that the
University's representatives at the
meetings "agreed in principle
with serving non-Union lettuce,
and we had to determine
reasonable alternatives."
Alternatives suggested
included serving non-local,
non-union lettuce, non-iceberg

lettuce or several California
brands, such as "Black Eagle",
none of which are covered by the
boycott.
"The Florida iceberg chosen
by Tanglos is slightly cheaper
and leafier than Union lettuce
that had been served," Ivanhoe
explained.
The Chaplain stated that no
problems are anticipated in
obtaining the new produce," but
we may need to look for another
state, other than Florida, if the
season there ends."
Wickwire commented that his
office had received several
complaints from students asking
what could be done to support
the boycott. He cited Chavez's
speech and recent publicity in
major newspapers on the boycott
of Gallo wines as motivating
forces in finding a supplier of
non-Union lettuce.
Ivanhoe stated that he had
received "under 10 complaints
from students. They weren't very
persistent, but we decided to
cooperate with the boycott, if we
could do it without hurting the
food service."
Tomorrow, Wickwire has
schedule a meeting at Loyola
College and one at Hopkins
Medical School on Thursday to
see if similar boycotts can be
instituted there.

THE EXORCIST IN 58 MINUTES

You can do it, too. So far over 550,000 other people have done it. People who
have different jobs, different IQs, different interests, different educations have
completed the course. Our graduates are people from all walks of life. These
people have all taken a course developed by Evelyn Wood, a prominent
educator. Practically all of them at least tripled their reading speed with equal or
better comprehension. Most have increased it even more.
Think for a moment what that means. All of them—even the slowest—now read
an average novel in less than two hours. They read an entire issue of Time or
Newsweek in 35 minutes. They don't skip or skim. They read every word. They
use no machines. Instead, they let the material they're reading determine how
fast they read. And mark this well: they actually understand more, remember
more, and enjoy more than when they read slowly. That's right! They
understand more. They remember more. They enjoy more. You can do the same
thing—the place to learn more about it is at a free speed reading lesson.

At That Speed, The 403 Pages Come Across
With More Impact Than The Movie.
In Living Blood, You Might Say.

The staff of President Nixon completed this course in June 1970. The same one

Come to a Mini-Lesson and find out. It is free to you and you will leave with a
better understanding of why it works. One thing that might bother you about
your reading speed is that someone might find out how slow it is. The
instructors at the Evelyn Wood Reading Dynamics Free Speed Reading lesson
will let you keep your secret. It's true we practice the first step to improved
reading at a Mini-Lesson and we will increase your reading speed on the spot, but
the results will remain your secret. Plan to attend a free Mini-Lesson and learn

Sunday Experience discusses the "age of the rip-off"
By ELLEN L. BERNHARD
Last week's Sunday
Experience program, sponsored
by the Office of the Chaplain,
presented "The Great Rip-Off", a
panel disucssion between Student
Council President Andy Savitz
Bob Ivanhoe, a member of th(
Union Governing Board, Hono
Commission Chairwoman Ann
Connor, and Judge Gerstung of
the Baltimore City Criminal
Court.
Concurring that this is "the
age of the rip-off," the panelists

discussed the question of
punishment for Hopkins'
students caught stealing on
campus. Savitz said that he was
unwilling to take a hard line
attitude because he sees "where
and why the problems arise."
"The worst example of a
rip-off is in political leaders who
should set examples, but don't,"
he said, citing Watergate and the
recent pardon of former
President Richard Nixon by
President Gerald Ford. "I don't
believe the problems of the

University can be solved until
someone solves the problems of
the nation."
Judge Gerstung, a Hopkins
alumnus, advocated a hardline
intolerance of crime. Illustrating
a "decline of morals," he asserted
that when he was a Hopkins
student during the 1950's, crime
on the campus was not as
widespread as it is now.
"Leaders in society have
looked too much to the people,"
said the Judge in refutation of
Savitz's statement. "The people

Saga positions remain unfilled
WORK/STUDY, from page 1
put our organization together
and trying to make it make
sense,- Denton said.
Many students did not receive
their first pay-checks because
they did not have all the
necessary forms signed and filled
out in time, revealed Joyce
Buchanan, Assistant Director of
Financial Aid.
Ruth Read, Director of
Student Employment, asserted
that this year's operation of
Work/Study is not as smooth as
last year, since information
regarding Work/Study students
and positions available has to
come through Financial Aid
before they come to her.
The one main problem not yet
resolved in the operation of the
program is that there are still

students who are in need of
Work/Study jobs, but also
Work/Study positions that have
yet to be filled, disclosed Read.
Saga has been alotted 20
Work/Study positions, although
only four of them have been

Hopkins Blue Jays kicked in the teeth by F&M Mules
By STEPHEN LEVIN
It was a dismal Saturday night
at Homewood Field as the
Hopkins football team was badly
beaten, 63-13, by the -unbeaten
Diplomats of Franklin &
Marshall. A school which focuses
all the energies of its athletic
department on their football
program, Franklin & Marshall
always has a fine team and are a
perennial conference
powerhouse. They are the

NEWS-LETTER

defending champs and boast 17
returning starters from last year's
8-1 squad (including a 28-7 win
over the Blue Jays).
This year's Diplomat squad
proved to be no bunch of
slouches either. Boasting an
offense that could move either
on the ground or through the air,
the Lancaster eleven ran up 555
yards in total offense on the
seemingly helpless Blue Jay
defense. F&M quarterback Joe

Coviello paced the Diplomats
aerial attack which (utilizing 3
QB's) completed a spectacular 81
or 28 passes for 227 yards, 4
touchdowns and no
interceptions. On the ground, the
Diplomats made it look easy as
they ripped through the Hopkins
defense for 328 yards in 56
carries (an incredible average of
over 5.8 yards per carry).
Leading the onslaught was the
Diplomats top rusher, Ted

Blue Jay hooters blank the Bears
By JOHN BLOOMENTHAL
The Hopkins booters collected
their first victory of the season,
blanking the Bears of Ursinus
College 3-0 Saturday.
From the outset, the game was
really no contest. Hopkins had
little difficulty in overpowering
their rivals and glided. easily to
their first season victory. The win
left the Blue Jays 1-1 in the
conference and 1-2- overall.
Freshman Gary Cunningham
put the Blue Jays on top early in
the first period, scoring a head
shot oof an assist! by Gary
Ignatowski. Only 48 seconds had
elapsed on the time clock when
Cunningham blasted in the first
goal. Cunningham put in another
goal 28 minutes later on an assist
by Tom Myrick. Cunningham put
in Hopkins third and final goal
late in the second period from an
assist by Larry McGowan.
Cunningham
With three goals to his credit
for the day, Cunningham was just
one goal short of the Hopkins
record for the most 'goals scored
in one game. That record is
currently held by last year's top
scorer Roberto Arguero.
It was a good day for others
on the squad as well. Coach
Robert Oliver called deep back
Ami Cohen's play "admirable."
Bruce Casenave, who has
developed rapidly as the season
has progressed, now owning a

spot on the starting lineup,
"played one of the best games in
his career at Hopkins."
The statistic of the contest
were extremely lopsided.
Hopkins took 27 shots on goal
and had 11 corner kicks. Ursinus,

on the defensive most of the
game, managed to get off only 8
shots on goal and only 2
cornerkicks.
The Blue Jays face Towson
State tomorrow at 4 p.m. at
Homewood Field.

Tourney for local community
By ROBERT ROSENWASSER
The second annual Mixed
Doubles Tournament will be held
October 12, 13 and 14. This
event, sponsored by the Johns
Hopkins University, is open to
undergraduates, graduate
students and faculty members.
Entry forms are available in
the office of the Athletic Center.
Eligibility requirements are
minimal. At least one person of
the mixed doubles team must be
an undergraduate, graduate
student or faculty member from
within any division of the
university. If you have a partner,
fine. If you need a partner,
arrangements will try to be made
by the sponsors of the
tournament.
Entry
An entry fee will be charged to
each entering team. The fee is
only one dollar and is used to
help defray the cost of the
awards. Also, each team must

supply one can of unused high
quality tennis balls. Tennis balls
may be purchased at cost at the
Athletic Center. The entry fee
may be paid in advance at the
Athletic Center or to Joyce
McGonnigal at the time of the
first match.
First round matches will be
played at 9 a.m. Saturday,
October 12. The tournament will
be played on the Homewood
Tennis Courts. Entrants will
receive a complete draw with
times the week of October 7.
Awards
Awards will be given to the
finalist winners and runners-up.
Matches will consist of the
best 2 out of 3 sets. A nine point
tie breaker will be played at 6-6
of any set.
The deadline for all entries
must be received on or before
October 9. In case the
tournament is postponed due to

season, the group will stay tight
further and further into the race.
